content.title: Arterial Embolectomy
content.definition: Arterial embolectomy is the surgical removal of embolic material from an artery, typically performed emergently for acute limb ischemia using a balloon-tipped catheter (Fogarty catheter) introduced through an arteriotomy.

indications.primary: Acute limb ischemia (ALI) due to embolic occlusion
indications.classic_presentation: Sudden onset 6 Ps: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia, Paresthesias, Paralysis
indications.timing: Best outcomes within 6 hours of symptom onset
indications.salvageability: Viable or marginally threatened limb (Rutherford I-IIa)

embolism_sources.cardiac: Most common - atrial fibrillation, MI, valve disease, endocarditis

embolism_vs_thrombosis.embolism: Sudden onset, no claudication history, identifiable source, normal contralateral pulses
embolism_vs_thrombosis.thrombosis: Prior claudication, PAD risk factors, bilateral disease

fogarty_catheter.technique: Pass beyond clot, inflate balloon, withdraw extracting thrombus

access.femoral: Most common - accessed through groin incision
access.popliteal: For below-knee embolism when femoral not possible

surgical_technique.fasciotomy: Consider prophylactically if prolonged ischemia (>4-6 hours)

learning_objectives: Distinguish embolic from thrombotic occlusion clinically
clinical_pearls: 6 Ps: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia, Paresthesia, Paralysis
Embolectomy preferred for embolic occlusion; bypass or thrombolysis may be needed for thrombosis
Always evaluate for embolic source (cardiac most common)
Consider prophylactic fasciotomy for prolonged ischemia (>4-6 hours)
